questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a tremor in his right hand for the past three months. The tremor has increased in intensity and he is unable to perform his daily activities. When he wakes up in the morning, his pillow is soaked in saliva. During this period, he has been unable to concentrate in his college classes. He has had several falls over the past month. He has no past history of serious illness. He appears healthy. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a broad-based gait. There is a low frequency tremor that affects the patient's right hand to a greater extent than his left. When the patient holds his arms fully abducted with his elbows flexed, he has a bilateral low frequency arm tremor that increases in amplitude the longer he holds his arms up. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Dysmetria is present. A photograph of the patient's eye is shown. Mental status examination shows a restricted affect. The rate and rhythm of his speech is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A chelating agent such as penicillamine is the treatment of choice to reduce the extremely high levels of copper in patients with Wilson disease. Treatment should be administered gradually over the course of 3–6 months. Once acute treatment is completed and copper levels are closer to normal, maintenance therapy with a low copper diet and either low-dose penicillamine or zinc salts is used. In patients who cannot tolerate penicillamine for acute treatment, trientine or zinc salts may be used.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a first-line treatment for essential tremor, the most common cause of tremor. Essential tremor is also an action tremor and commonly affects the hands. Vocal muscle involvement can cause a tremulous voice, which can be mistaken for dysarthria. However, the tremor is typically symmetric and would not explain this patient's other findings (e.g., drooling, affect change, ocular findings). Additionally, the wing-beating tremor seen in this patient is not typical of essential tremor.

C) INCORRECT:

Deferoxamine is the treatment of choice for acute iron poisoning, which occurs after ingestion of iron supplements (e.g., multivitamins) either unintentionally (children) or intentionally (adults). Acute iron poisoning typically manifests within hours of ingestion with abdominal pain, nausea, and hematemesis, due to direct effects on the gastrointestinal mucosa. The onset and nature of this patient's symptoms are not consistent with iron toxicity. Deferoxamine is also occasionally used to treat hemochromatosis, a condition that leads to abnormal iron deposition in specific organs. This patient's condition is more likely caused by copper accumulation in the body.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) are indicated as acute treatment for many autoimmune neurologic diseases (e.g., Sydenham chorea, multiple sclerosis). Sydenham chorea resulting from rheumatic fever manifests with abnormal rhythmic/jerking movements in children following streptococcal infection. No other autoimmune neurologic diseases commonly cause tremor. The wing-flapping postural tremor in this adult patient makes another non-autoimmune disease much more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is the treatment of choice for Parkinson disease (PD), which causes resting tremor, affect changes, and falls. However, PD is associated with a shuffling gait, rather than this patient's broad-based gait, and it would not explain this patient's ocular findings, drooling, or hyperreflexia. Moreover, tremor caused by PD improves with activity, whereas this patient's tremor is exacerbated by it. Finally, PD primarily affects older adults.
questions.hint: The combination of a wing-beating tremor, excessive drooling, hyperreflexia, signs of depression (restricted affect, inability to concentrate), gait abnormalities, and dysmetria in an individual with Kayser-Fleischer rings suggests Wilson disease.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a fall associated with a 6-month history of increasing difficulty walking. Over the last year, his friends have also noticed his speech becoming slower. During this period, he also gave up his hobby of playing video games because he has become clumsy with his hands. His father died of esophageal varices at the age of 40 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. He appears sad. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His speech is slurred and monotonous; his gait is unsteady. Examination shows scleral icterus and some drooling. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1 to 2 cm below the left costal margin. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Ventriculomegaly on CT scan of the brain
Ground glass hepatocytes on liver biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased transferrin saturation is characteristic of hemochromatosis, which commonly manifests with hepatosplenomegaly and signs of liver failure (e.g., jaundice). Neurological deficits may also occur if hepatic encephalopathy develops. However, other signs of chronic liver disease, such as ascites or peripheral edema would be expected. Additionally, the neurological symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy predominantly involve neuropsychiatric symptoms (disorientation and altered consciousness) rather than progressive motor dysfunction. Furthermore, most patients with hemochromatosis present > 30 years of age, and other common features, such as bronzed skin, arthralgia, diabetes, and/or cardiomyopathy, are missing.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample (Prussian blue stain)

Prussian blue stains the iron deposits dark blue (green arrows) and the nuclei bright red. A portal triad (P; green overlay) is visible in the lower left corner.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased number of CAG repeats (on genetic analysis) is diagnostic of Huntington's disease (HD), which may manifest with motor deficits like difficulties walking, talking, and playing video games. However, clinical hallmarks of HD, such as chorea, sensory deficits, and/or autonomic symptoms (hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence), are absent in this patient. In addition, HD does not affect the liver.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands are seen on CSF electrophoresis in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), which may also manifest with neurological symptoms such as difficulty in talking or walking. However, this patient does not have the most common symptoms of MS such as sensory deficits and vision loss. Also, MS would not explain this patient's jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventriculomegaly (on CT/MRI scan of the brain) is seen in hydrocephalus. Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is generally associated with gait abnormalities, but the condition primarily occurs in older individuals and other characteristic features, such as dementia and urinary incontinence, are absent in this patient. Hydrocephalus can also be caused by obstruction of CSF passage (e.g., by brain tumors and/or congenital malformations), but such patients would present with features of elevated ICP (e.g., papilledema). Moreover, the liver is usually not affected by conditions that cause hydrocephalus.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Ground glass hepatocytes on liver biopsy are diagnostic of chronic HBV hepatitis, which manifests with hepatosplenomegaly and signs of liver failure (e.g., jaundice). Neurological deficits may also occur if hepatic encephalopathy develops. However, other signs of chronic liver disease, such as ascites or peripheral edema would be expected. Additionally, the neurological symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy predominantly involve neuropsychiatric symptoms (disorientation and altered consciousness) rather than progressive motor dysfunction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Most of the hepatocytes have a pale, homogeneous cytoplasm (ground glass hepatocytes; examples marked by blue overlay).

Ground glass hepatocytes are often found in chronic hepatitis B infection.

F) CORRECT:

The presence of dysarthria, gait disturbance, drooling, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly in combination with a family history of esophageal varices, which are commonly caused by cirrhosis, suggests Wilson disease. In Wilson disease, a genetic mutation in the ATP7B gene (Wilson gene) causes a defect in ceruloplasmin, a copper transporting protein, leading to a decrease in copper secretion into the bile. The resulting accumulation of copper in the liver causes hepatocyte injury, which can ultimately result in cirrhosis. The discharge of excess copper into the bloodstream leads to an accumulation of copper in the other tissues, such as the central nervous system (basal ganglia, brain stem, cerebellum) and corneas, causing the extrahepatic symptoms seen in this patient. The impaired copper transport also inhibits the incorporation of copper into apoceruloplasmin, resulting in low serum ceruloplasmin, which is diagnostic of Wilson disease.
questions.hint: Examination of the cornea in this patient would very likely show Kayser-Fleischer rings.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of progressive difficulty walking, slowed speech, and a tremor for the past 5 months. Her grandfather died of bleeding esophageal varices at the age of 42 years. She does not drink alcohol. She is alert and oriented but has a flat affect. Her speech is slurred and monotonous. Examination shows a broad-based gait and a low-frequency tremor of her left hand. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A photograph of the patient's left eye is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Positive anti-hepatitis B virus IgG antibodies
Destruction of lobular bile ducts on liver biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin deposits of lipid-laden macrophages are the hallmark cutaneous manifestations of hyperlipidemia (xanthomas, xanthelasma). Lipid disorders can result in lipid deposition within the cornea, which manifests as yellow or gray discoloration of the corneal margin (arcus lipoides corneae). In contrast, this patient's Kayser-Fleischer rings are brown in color. Hyperlipidemia would manifest with premature coronary artery disease rather than symptoms of liver and neuropsychiatric disease.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased number of CAG repeats (on genetic analysis) is diagnostic of Huntington disease, which may present with motor deficits like difficulties walking and talking. However, clinical hallmarks of HD, such as chorea, sensory deficits, and/or autonomic symptoms (hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence), are absent in this patient. In addition, HD does not affect the liver.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive anti-hepatitis B virus IgG antibodies may indicate chronic hepatitis B infection (or prior exposure), which presents with hepatosplenomegaly and signs of liver failure (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly). Neurological deficits may also occur if hepatic encephalopathy develops. However, other signs of chronic liver disease, such as ascites or peripheral edema would be expected. In addition, the neurological symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy predominantly manifest as disorientation and altered consciousness rather than progressive motor dysfunction.

D) CORRECT:

Low serum ceruloplasmin concentration is diagnostic of Wilson disease (WD). In WD, an autosomal recessive genetic mutation in the ATP7B gene (Wilson gene) leads to a defect in a copper-transporting protein, resulting in impaired incorporation of copper into apoceruloplasmin and, consequently, low serum ceruloplasmin. The decrease in copper transport through the cell causes copper accumulation, especially within the liver, CNS (basal ganglia, brain stem, cerebellum), and cornea (Kayser-Fleischer rings). WD typically manifests with a combination of hepatic symptoms (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, cirrhosis), neurologic symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, gait disturbance, tremor), and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., flattened affect).

E) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of lobular bile ducts on liver biopsy is diagnostic of primary biliary cholangitis. PBC predominantly affects middle-aged women (peak incidence of 30–65 years). Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding of PBC; Kayser-Fleischer rings are a rare manifestation. PBC does not cause progressive motor dysfunction, tremor, or dysarthria. Moreover, this patients lacks other features of PBC, such as generalized pruritus, hyperpigmentation, jaundice, or xanthomas.
questions.hint: The brown discoloration of the corneal margin is a Kayser-Fleischer ring.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a progressively worsening tremor in his hands and multiple falls over the past 3 months. The tremor occurs both at rest and with movement. He also reports decreased concentration and a loss of interest in his normal activities over this time period. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. He drinks two alcoholic beverages daily and does not use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam shows mild jaundice, a flapping tremor, and a broad-based gait. Serum studies show:


Aspartate aminotransferase
554 U/L


Hepatitis B surface antibody
positive


Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Ceruloplasmin

5.5 mg/dL (normal: 19.0-31.0 mg/dL)


Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tenofovir is the first-line therapy for hepatitis B infection. This patient has a positive hepatitis B surface antibody and a negative hepatitis B surface antigen, which is indicative of either prior vaccination or a resolved prior infection, neither of which would require treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Prednisolone can be used for the management of severe alcohol-associated hepatitis, which can also present with jaundice and elevated AST. A patient abusing alcohol could present with an ataxic gait (due to Wernicke encephalopathy) and/or asterixis (secondary to alcohol withdrawal or hepatic encephalopathy), findings which are similar to the tremor and gait disturbances seen in this patient. However, this patient's alcohol consumption is within the CDC guidelines for moderate alcohol consumption (14 drinks/week for men). Additionally, alcohol-associated hepatitis would not explain a low ceruloplasmin level.

C) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is used for the treatment of Parkinson disease, which can also present with extrapyramidal symptoms (flapping tremor, broad-based gait). However, Parkinson does not affect the liver and would not cause jaundice, increased AST, or decreased ceruloplasmin.

D) INCORRECT:

Deferoxamine is used to treat hemochromatosis, a disease characterized by chronic iron overload, leading to iron accumulates, especially in the liver (increased risk of HCC), pancreas, skin (“bronze diabetes”), heart, pituitary, and joints. Although hemochromatosis can also cause liver disease with an elevated AST and jaundice, it does not result in extrapyramidal symptoms or a low ceruloplasmin level. Also, it most commonly presents after age 40.

E) CORRECT:

Penicillamine facilitates renal excretion of copper and is considered a first-line treatment for Wilson disease. Trientine hydrochloride and zinc salts can be used as alternative therapies. Treatment with a chelating agent should be administered gradually over the course of 3–6 months, as mobilizing the copper stored in tissues too rapidly may exacerbate neurological symptoms.
questions.hint: This young patient presents with extrapyramidal symptoms, jaundice, and a low ceruloplasmin level, which is consistent with Wilson disease.

questions.text: A healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the physician with her husband for preconception counseling. Her husband is healthy but she is concerned because her brother was recently diagnosed with a genetic liver condition for which he takes penicillamine. Her father-in-law has liver cirrhosis and a tremor. The results of genetic testing show that both the patient and her husband are carriers of a mutation in the ATP7B gene. Which of the following is the chance that this patient’s offspring will eventually develop the hereditary condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For a 0% chance (4 x 0 = 0) of the couple having an affected offspring, at least one member must not be a carrier. However, autosomal recessive disorders, such as Wilson disease, require one defective allele from each parent to manifest clinically.

B) INCORRECT:

For a 100% probability of the couple having an affected child (4 x 0.25 = 1), both must be affected individuals (homozygous). However, clinically manifested autosomal recessive disorders are usually inherited from two unaffected carriers (heterozygous) that pass on the mutated gene, and the parents of this patient did not develop the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

For a 75% probability of the couple having an affected child, both parents must be heterozygous for the defective allele in an autosomal dominant inherited disorder (3 x 0.25 = 0.75). However, if both parents were heterozygous dominant, they both would develop the disease. Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder. Two carrier parents would not render this probability of affected offspring.

D) CORRECT:

Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes for a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase associated with the biliary excretion of copper. Since both parents are carriers, there is a 50% chance that each one of them will pass on the defective allele. Therefore, the offspring has an overall 25% probability of developing the condition (0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25).

E) INCORRECT:

50% (2x (0.5 × 0.5) = 0.5) is the chance of the couple having a carrier child, since genetic testing shows that they are both carriers of the defective allele. However, since autosomal recessive disorders require two alleles of a gene to be defective, carrier offspring would not have Wilson disease.
questions.hint: Hepatitis, neurological symptoms (e.g., tremor), and cirrhosis are manifestations of Wilson disease, a disorder characterized by excessive accumulation of copper in the body.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend, who found her confused and lying on the bathroom floor with black stool in the toilet.
The patient is unable to answer any questions, but her boyfriend reports that she has been acting strangely the past few months, with more impulsive behavior. He has also noticed her being clumsy around their apartment and that she has developed an arm tremor. Last week, he noticed that her eyes appeared yellow, but she has not complained of any abdominal pain or rectal bleeding.
He does not think that she has been drinking substantial amounts of alcohol or using illicit drugs, and he is not aware of her taking any new medications or frequently using any over-the-counter medications.
On physical examination, her temperature is 38.5°C, her heart rate is 114 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 94/52 mm Hg, her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 92% with 2 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. She is lethargic and responds only to painful or loud stimuli; she does not speak or answer questions.
Jaundice and scleral icterus are present, but there are no spider angiomas. Her cardiac examination is normal except for tachycardia, and her lungs exhibit diminished breath sounds at the bases bilaterally. Her abdomen is distended with a fluid wave, and she winces somewhat with deep palpation of the right upper quadrant. Rectal examination is notable for black, sticky stool. She does not have leg edema or rashes.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


International normalized ratio
3.9
—


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9800
4500–11,000


Hematocrit (%)
26
36–46


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
83
80–100


Platelet count (per mm3)
74,000
150,000–350,000


Total protein (g/dL)
4.8
5.5–8.0


Albumin (g/dL)
2.1
3.5–5.5


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
867
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
1843
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
17
30–120


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
6.4
0.3–1.0


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
4.1
0.1–0.3


Acetaminophen (μg/mL)
1
10–30


Ethanol is not detected in the blood, and a urine toxicology screen is negative.
Doppler ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant shows hepatomegaly and ascites but no evidence of portal or hepatic vein thrombosis and no dilated intra- or extrahepatic bile ducts.
Which one of the following tests is appropriate to evaluate for the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease can, on rare occasions, manifest with abnormal liver enzyme levels, and the first step in evaluation is to measure tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA levels. However, it does not manifest with acute liver failure or any of the other clinical features in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

An antimitochondrial antibody test is frequently positive in primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). HFE genotyping is used to evaluate for hereditary hemochromatosis. Both hemochromatosis and PBC can cause chronic liver disease and cirrhosis but would not be expected to cause acute liver failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute viral hepatitis can cause acute liver failure; although this can occur with hepatitis C virus, it is more likely with hepatitis A and B. In addition, viral hepatitis would not be expected to cause a low alkaline phosphatase level, and the ALT level would be expected to be higher than the AST level. If acute viral hepatitis is suspected, a hepatitis C viral load should also be measured because the antibody test may not be positive until 12 weeks after infection.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has acute liver failure as evidenced by abnormal liver-enzyme levels, coagulopathy (an elevated international normalized ratio with evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding), and encephalopathy. Determining the underlying cause of the liver failure is important because it will affect management.

Wilson disease, although rare, should be suspected in this patient, given her young age, her history of psychological and neurologic symptoms, and her laboratory results, including a low ratio of alkaline phosphatase to total bilirubin (<4) in the setting of elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels (AST-to-ALT ratio >2; levels <2000 U/liter). Renal failure and a Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia can also occur in acute Wilson disease (although this patient’s anemia is most likely due to gastrointestinal bleeding).

A low serum ceruloplasmin level (<0.1 g/liter) in this context would be suggestive of Wilson disease, although it is not sufficient for diagnosis; there have been reports of low positive predictive values of isolated ceruloplasmin levels for the diagnosis of Wilson disease, and ceruloplasmin is an acute-phase reactant that could be falsely high in the acute setting. Thus, before a diagnosis of Wilson disease can be made, confirmatory testing should be done, including serum copper concentration, 24-hour urinary copper excretion, and an ocular slit-lamp examination for Kayser-Fleischer rings.

Key learning point: Acute liver failure in a young woman with recent behavioral and neurologic changes, gastrointestinal bleeding, a low alkaline phosphatase level, and elevated aminotransferase levels with an AST-to-ALT ratio >2 should prompt evaluation for Wilson disease.

E) INCORRECT:

HFE genotyping is used to evaluate for hereditary hemochromatosis. An antimitochondrial antibody test is frequently positive in primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). Both hemochromatosis and PBC can cause chronic liver disease and cirrhosis but would not be expected to cause acute liver failure.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with no notable medical history reports having intermittent mild pain in her upper right abdomen for the past 2 months. Her father notes that her appetite has been diminished but that her abdominal discomfort does not seem to be associated with eating meals. She is an avid basketball player and has also been reporting pain in her right lower chest while playing.
She passes one regular bowel movement every day and has had no vomiting. She reports no dysphagia, odynophagia, fever, cough, dyspnea, pleurisy, night sweats, sick contacts, or recent travel. She has not yet started menstruating and does not report fatigue or lethargy. She has taken no medications recently and denies any toxic ingestions. Her immunizations are up to date. Her BMI has been consistently at the 75th percentile. She is in the ninth grade and has always performed well in classes.
Physical examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9000
4500–13,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13
12–16


Hematocrit (%)
38.5
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
220,000
150,000–450,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
85
78–102


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour)
4
0–20


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
1
0–5


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
255
5–30


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
334
13–35


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.9
<1.5


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.1
0.2


Gamma-glutamyltransferase (U/liter)
22
5–24


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
160
100–320


Total protein (g/dL)
7.0
6–8


Albumin (g/dL)
4.5
3.6–5.2


Prothrombin time
13
11–14


International normalized ratio
1.1
—


Total immunoglobulin G (mg/dL)
1100
509–1580


Ferritin (ng/mL)
110
7–140


Serum ceruloplasmin (mg/dL)
19
20.8–43.2


Testing is negative for anti-smooth muscle antibodies, anti-liver-kidney microsomal antibodies, hepatitis B antibodies, and hepatitis C antibodies. The alpha1-antitrypsin phenotype is MM (normal).
Slit-lamp examination reveals copper deposition into the Descemet membrane.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reassurance and repeat liver function testing in 3 months
Genetic testing for common mutations in the ATP7B gene
Diet and lifestyle modification aimed at weight loss

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and repeat liver function testing is not an appropriate strategy for a patient who has active hepatitis of unknown etiology and an incomplete workup for Wilson disease. The differential diagnosis of hepatitis is broad and includes severe, life-threatening conditions that require attention.

B) INCORRECT:

Genetic screening for disease-causing mutations in the ATP7B gene is considered a later step of analysis and would not be needed in this patient if the 24-hour urinary copper excretion is consistent with Wilson disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Diet and lifestyle modification, with the aim of weight reduction, is the preferred management approach for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This condition typically occurs in patients with overweight or obesity, whereas this patient has a normal BMI. NAFLD is a diagnosis of exclusion, and other causes of liver disease, including Wilson disease, must be ruled out first.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has hepatitis with a negative workup for infectious and autoimmune etiologies and normal growth and development. In this context, she requires screening for Wilson disease.

Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disease of copper metabolism. A defect in the ATP7B gene impairs copper excretion, resulting in an accumulation of copper in the hepatocytes. Once liver cells become overloaded, excess copper is distributed to other tissues, including the brain, kidneys, heart, and corneas.

The clinical manifestations of Wilson disease vary widely, ranging from asymptomatic to subacute hepatitis, acute hepatitis, or fulminant hepatic failure. Because copper accumulation and toxicity take time, clinical liver disease rarely manifests before 3 years of age. In addition to liver involvement, Wilson disease may have neuropsychiatric manifestations, such as mood changes, declining academic performance, and dysarthria; these typically develop in the second or third decade of life but can also occur in teenagers.

Early recognition of Wilson disease is critical because the disease is progressive if left untreated. However, diagnosis in asymptomatic patients is difficult and requires a high index of suspicion. No single test can be used to diagnose Wilson disease or to rule it out.

Recent guidelines from ESPGHAN (the European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition) recommend using the Ferenci score to guide the workup, with a diagnosis of Wilson disease reached once a score of 4 is reached. The first stage of the workup includes:

• Measurement of ceruloplasmin, a copper-binding protein. Although a low serum level of this protein is suggestive of disease, a normal level alone cannot rule out the disease. Approximately 20% of children with Wilson disease have normal ceruloplasmin levels. If a patient has a normal or borderline ceruloplasmin level but concern for Wilson disease remains (as in this case), additional investigation is required.
• Ophthalmologic examination to look for Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings with copper deposition into the Descemet membrane. Although KF rings are not common in children with non-neuropsychiatric presentations of Wilson disease, they remain an important part of the evaluation.
• Studies of 24-hour urinary copper excretion.

This patient’s Ferenci score would be 3, given the data currently available — slightly reduced serum ceruloplasmin, presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings, no classic neuropsychiatric symptoms, and no signs of a hemolytic anemia. A 24-hour urinary copper excretion of >40 μg would raise the Ferenci score to 4 and potentially obviate the need for more invasive testing.

Key learning point: Screening for Wilson disease includes measuring serum ceruloplasmin levels and 24-hour urinary copper excretion.

E) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy would allow for histology to examine alternative etiologies in addition to Wilson disease, but this procedure is invasive and carries a risk of serious complications, including hemorrhage. Thus, a study of 24-hour urinary copper excretion should be performed first.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the office because of a fall associated with a 6-month history of increasing difficulty walking. Over the last year, his friends have also noticed his speech becoming slower. During this period, he also gave up his hobby of playing video games because he has become clumsy with his hands. His father died of esophageal varices at the age of 40 years. His speech is slurred and monotonous; his gait is unsteady. Examination shows scleral icterus and some drooling. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1 to 2 cm below the left costal margin. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Ground glass hepatocytes on liver biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased transferrin saturation is characteristic of hemochromatosis, which commonly manifests with hepatosplenomegaly and signs of liver failure (e.g., jaundice). Neurological deficits may also occur if hepatic encephalopathy develops. However, other signs of chronic liver disease, such as ascites or peripheral edema would be expected. Additionally, the neurological symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy predominantly involve neuropsychiatric symptoms (disorientation and altered consciousness) rather than progressive motor dysfunction. Furthermore, most patients with hemochromatosis present > 30 years of age, and other common features, such as bronzed skin, arthralgia, diabetes, and/or cardiomyopathy, are missing.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased number of CAG repeats (on genetic analysis) is diagnostic of Huntington disease (HD), which may manifest with motor deficits like difficulties walking, talking, and playing video games. However, clinical hallmarks of HD, such as chorea, sensory deficits, and/or autonomic symptoms (hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence), are absent in this patient. In addition, HD does not affect the liver.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands are seen on CSF electrophoresis in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), which may also manifest with neurological symptoms such as difficulty in talking or walking. However, this patient does not have the most common symptoms of MS such as sensory deficits and vision loss. Also, MS would not explain this patient's jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly.

D) INCORRECT:

Ground glass hepatocytes on liver biopsy are diagnostic of chronic HBV hepatitis, which manifests with hepatosplenomegaly and signs of liver failure (e.g., jaundice). Neurological deficits may also occur if hepatic encephalopathy develops. However, other signs of chronic liver disease, such as ascites or peripheral edema would be expected. Additionally, the neurological symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy predominantly involve neuropsychiatric symptoms (disorientation and altered consciousness) rather than progressive motor dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of dysarthria, gait disturbance, drooling, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly in combination with a family history of esophageal varices, which are commonly caused by cirrhosis, suggests Wilson disease. In Wilson disease, a genetic mutation in the ATP7B gene (Wilson gene) causes a defect in ceruloplasmin, a copper transporting protein, leading to a decrease in copper secretion into the bile. The resulting accumulation of copper in the liver causes hepatocyte injury, which can ultimately result in cirrhosis. The discharge of excess copper into the bloodstream leads to an accumulation of copper in the other tissues, such as the central nervous system (basal ganglia, brain stem, cerebellum) and corneas, causing the extrahepatic symptoms seen in this patient. The impaired copper transport also inhibits the incorporation of copper into apoceruloplasmin, resulting in low serum ceruloplasmin, which is diagnostic of Wilson disease.
questions.hint: Examination of the cornea in this patient would very likely show Kayser-Fleischer rings.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty with both hands for three months. He reports uncontrollable tremors, occasional slurred speech, and increasing irritability. He is otherwise healthy. He has a paternal uncle who died from uncertain liver disease in his 40s. Physical examination shows mild jaundice and subtle psychiatric changes. A brownish discoloration is noted along the corneal limbus on routine ophthalmic exam. Serum aminotransferases are mildly elevated.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis often presents in young to middle-aged females with liver inflammation, jaundice, and elevated aminotransferases. However, it lacks the neurological symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings seen here. The absence of autoimmune markers and the presence of neuropsychiatric symptoms suggest a different etiology.

B) CORRECT:

Wilson disease manifests with neurological symptoms such as tremors, dysarthria, and psychiatric changes due to copper accumulation in the brain. The brownish discoloration at the corneal limbus indicates Kayser-Fleischer rings, a result of copper deposition in the eye. Elevated serum aminotransferases and jaundice reflect hepatic involvement, as the liver is central to copper metabolism. A mutation in the ATP7B gene impairs biliary copper excretion, leading to copper buildup in the liver, brain, and cornea. The family history of liver disease supports this autosomal recessive disorder.

Key learning point: Wilson disease is characterized by copper accumulation, leading to liver dysfunction, neurological symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are pathognomonic for the condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis, an iron overload disorder, typically presents in middle-aged individuals with arthropathy, diabetes, and skin hyperpigmentation. The neurological symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings seen here are not characteristic of hemochromatosis. Additionally, the patient's age and mild liver enzyme elevation do not align with the typical presentation of this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease usually affects older individuals and presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. The patient's age, non-resting tremors, and dysarthria differ from typical Parkinsonian features. Additionally, jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and Kayser-Fleischer rings indicate a different pathophysiology involving hepatic dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with a three-month history of progressive tremor, dysarthria, and recent mood changes. She does not use illicit drugs or alcohol. Physical examination reveals mild muscular rigidity and a brownish-green ring at the periphery of both corneas on slit-lamp examination (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Alanine aminotransferase
55 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
50 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Creatinine
51 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Ceruloplasmin
100 mg/L
200 - 540 mg/L


Urine




 24-hour urine copper
3.0 μmol/day
< 1.6 μmol/day



Abdominal ultrasound: Mild hepatosplenomegaly
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to impaired copper transport, decreased biliary copper excretion, and copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues. This patient presents with neuropsychiatric symptoms, Kayser-Fleischer rings, low serum ceruloplasmin, and elevated urinary copper, all indicative of Wilson disease. Copper chelators (e.g., D-penicillamine, trientine) facilitate copper excretion through urine. Zinc salts (e.g., zinc acetate), which induce intestinal metallothionein synthesis and reduce dietary copper absorption, are suitable for maintenance therapy or asymptomatic Wilson disease. This patient has significant neurological symptoms, requiring active copper chelation for immediate reduction in copper toxicity.

Key learning point: Wilson's disease is characterized by copper accumulation and is treated with chelating agents like penicillamine to facilitate copper excretion.

B) INCORRECT:

Deferoxamine is an iron-chelating agent used for iron overload conditions like hereditary hemochromatosis. This patient has a copper accumulation disorder, as indicated by low ceruloplasmin, increased urinary copper, and neurological symptoms. Deferoxamine does not address copper accumulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid inhibits the intestinal absorption of cholesterol and reduces hepatic synthesis and secretion of endogenous cholesterol. It can be used to treat primary biliary cholangitis and cholesterol gallstone disease but is ineffective in treating Wilson disease.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are used for inflammatory conditions, such as autoimmune hepatitis, characterized by elevated transaminases and positive autoimmune serologies. This patient has low ceruloplasmin and increased urinary copper, indicating a metabolic defect in copper excretion, not an immune-mediated process.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressive fatigue, tremor, and mood changes over several months. His family reports increasing irritability and difficulty with speech. He denies alcohol or drug use. Examination shows mild jaundice, resting tremor, and dysarthria. Vital signs are stable. Laboratory results show AST 85 Units/L, ALT 92 Units/L, total bilirubin 2.1 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase 65 Units/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary hemochromatosis manifests with hepatic dysfunction. It does not typically cause neuropsychiatric symptoms. Also, additional findings like diabetes mellitus or bronze skin hyperpigmentation would also be seen. The combination of tremor, mood changes, and speech difficulties in this young adult makes hemochromatosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral hepatitis commonly causes elevated aminotransferases, jaundice, and systemic symptoms such as fatigue and malaise. However, viral hepatitis does not cause movement disorders, speech difficulties, or psychiatric disturbances. The chronic neuropsychiatric features in this patient suggest a metabolic rather than infectious etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency can cause chronic hepatic dysfunction. However, pulmonary manifestations would also be expected. Additionally, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency does not manifest with neurological symptoms such as tremor, dysarthria, or psychiatric changes, making it inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis causes chronic hepatic dysfunction. However, it does not manifest with movement disorders or mood changes.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Wilson disease manifests in young adults with the classic triad of hepatic dysfunction, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and movement disorders. The combination of elevated transaminases, mild jaundice, resting tremor, dysarthria, and mood changes in a 23-year-old is highly suggestive of Wilson disease. Diagnosis is confirmed with copper metabolism studies (serum ceruloplasmin, 24-hour urinary copper).
